Executive Summary for Chlorine

The Patapsco Wastewater Treatment Plant has the ability to store one ton chlorine containers both inside and outside of the chlorine facilities. It is equipped to store a maximum of 24 one-ton chlorine containers, twelve of which are stored within the building and are connected to the chlorination system, and twelve of which are stored outdoors.

Six chlorine containers sit atop a series of three hydraulic load scales while six are stored on floor level trunnions. Each scale weighs a pair of chlorine containers and is connected to one wall mounted scale dial. The scale dial provides a localized readout and enables the Operator to continuously monitor the available chlorine remaining in the containers.
     
The chlorination system is designed to allow to manifold twelve, one ton chlorine containers at a time, which are ready for service (connected). The twelve containers are manifolded using a yoke adapter, a container isolation valve and a flexible line leading to. a header valve. The chlorine supply can thus be isolated using either the container isolation valve at the header valve. Plan and flow diagrams of the chlorine system are included as Exhibit 4 in the Appendix.

From each of the manifolded containers, liquid chlorine is supplied under pressure into one evaporator.  Four liquid line pressure reliefs are installed between the manifolded containers and the evaporators to prevent any over pressurization condition.

Four 10,000 lb./day evaporators convert the liquid elemental chlorine into chlorine gas by using a hot water bath heat exchanger for vaporization. The evaporators include an automatic water level control system; a gas pressure relief system; high pressure, low temperature and low level water bath alarms for operational safety. The instrument panel of each evaporator has a water level indicator, a cathodic protection Ammeter and gauges for gas pressure and water temperature to allow monitoring.

From each of the evaporat

ors, the gaseous chlorine passes through a chlorine gas filter and into the Chlorinator Room. At this point, chlorine is supplied under pressure to one 10,000 lb./day, cabinet mounted, V-Notch Chlorinators. Each chlorinator contains a pressure regulating valve, a flow meter, a variable metering orifice, and a vacuum regulating valve. The vacuum regulating valves are the demarcation between the pressurized portion and the vacuum portion of the chlorine supply system. The valves greatly reduce the length of pressurized pipe and enables a large portion of the chlorine supply to be automatically shut??A? off by the closure of a vacuum-activated, spring loaded valve if loss of vacuum occurs for any reason.

Five of the chlorinators supply chlorine gas to the ejectors. The remaining five chlorinators produce concentrated chlorine solution which is piped to various application points throughout the plant.

Four ejectors are used to create a vacuum and pull chlorine gas into the vacuum regulating valves, through the chlorinators and into the ejector bodies. At the ejectors, the chlorine dissolves into water to form hydrochloric acid and flows through four three-inch diameter chlorine solution pipes to the Injection Building for application to the WWTP effluent prior to the chlorine contact tanks.

The chlorine system is under a vacuum from the ejector to the vacuum regulating valve of the chlorinator during operation. If the water supply to the ejector is stopped, or the operating vacuum is lost for any other reason, the spring-loaded vacuum regulating valve immediately closes to isolate the chlorinators from the gas supply. If the source of chlorine gas is exhausted, the valve closes to prevent excess vacuum levels from developing in the chlorine piping.

The vacuum gauge, pressure gauge, and chlorine gas flow meter, which are mounted on the front of each chlorinator cabinet, enable the operator to determine application characteristics and make adjustments. The optimum dos

age is determined by measuring the residual chlorine at the process control sampling points and adjusting the feed rate.
The following are the main control points for the chlorine feed system:

--Container Isolation Valves - shut-off valves for the chlorine container supplies.
--Header Valves - Secondary shut-off valves for the chlorine container supplies.
--Chlorine Ejector ??A? creates a vacuum and allows the vacuum regulator to withdraw chlorine gas from one ton container.
--Vacuum Regulating Valve - reduces the pressurized gas to a vacuum demand supply.

A major safety concern is a chlorine leak in Chlorination Building. The Bureau of Water and Wastewater has installed a wall mounted, Wallace & Tiernan chlorine gas detector located in the Chlorination Building. This device is mounted at eye level with a suction pipe located at floor level continuously sample air and detect any presence of chlorine gas.  
The facility uses an approximately 2,000 pounds per day (lb./day) of chlorine for disinfection.


Executive Summary for Sulfur Dioxide 

The Patapsco Wastewater Treatment Plant is equipped to store a maximum of seventeen one-ton sulfur dioxide containers, all of which are stored within the Dechlorination Building. Four cylinders are connected to the dechlorination system at any one time, while thirteen remain in the storage area. An overhead monorail system equipped with an electric hoist is available to transport the ton containers from the storage trunnions or cradles to the scale trunnions and vice-versa. The monorail system also has the ability to transport the containers to or from the loading/unloading area to the storage areas of the Dechlorination Building.

Four sulfur dioxide containers sit atop a series of two hydraulic load scales while thirteen (twelve full, one empty) are stored on floor level trunnions. Each scale weighs a pair of sulfur dioxide containers and is connected to two wall mounted scale dials. The scale dials provide a localized readou

t and enable the Operator to continuously monitor the available sulfur dioxide remaining in the containers.
     
The dechlorination system is designed to allow the manifolding of four, one-ton sulfur dioxide containers at a time, two of which are ready for service (connected) and thirteen of which are placed in stand-by (not connected). The four containers are manifolded using a yoke adapter, a container isolation valve and a flexible line leading to a header valve. Thus the sulfur dioxide supply can be isolated using either the container isolation valve or the header valve. 

From each of the manifolded containers, liquid sulfur dioxide is supplied under pressure into evaporators located in the SO2 Feeder Room. Two liquid line pressure relief valves are installed between the manifolded containers and the evaporators to prevent any over pressurization condition. Two 10,000 lb./day evaporators convert the liquid elemental sulfur dioxide into sulfur dioxide gas using a hot water bath heat exchanger for vaporization. The evaporators include an automatic water level control system, a gas pressure relief system, high pressure, low temperature and low level water bath alarms for operational safety. The instrument panel of each evaporator has a water level indicator, a cathodic protection Ammeter and gauges for gas pressure and water temperature to allow monitoring.

From each of the evaporators, the gaseous sulfur dioxide passes through a sulfur dioxide gas filter and into the S02 Injector Room. At this point, sulfur dioxide is supplied under pressure to one of four 500 lb/day and two 2,000 lb/day cabinet mounted, V-Notch sulfonators. Each sulfonator contains a pressure regulating valve, a flow meter, a variable metering orifice, and a vacuum regulating valve. The pressure regulating valves are the demarcation between the pressurized portion and the vacuum portion of the sulfur dioxide supply system. The valves greatly reduce the length of pressurized pipe and enable a larg

e portion of the sulfur dioxide supply to be automatically shut-off by the closure of a vacuum-activated, spring loaded valve if loss of vacuum occurs for any reason.
Five ejectors are used to create a vacuum and pull sulfur dioxide gas from the vacuum regulating valves, through the sulfonators and into the ejector bodies. At the ejectors, the sulfur dioxide dissolves into water to form sulfuric acid and flows through an 8-inch sulfur dioxide solution line into the S02 mixing basin.

The dechlorination system is under a vacuum from the ejector to the vacuum regulating valve of the sulfonator during operation. If the water supply to the ejector is stopped, or the operating vacuum is lost for any other reason, the spring??A?-loaded vacuum regulating valve immediately closes to isolate the sulfonator from the gas supply. If the source of sulfur dioxide gas is exhausted, the valve closes to prevent excess vacuum levels from developing in the sulfur dioxide piping.

The vacuum gauge, pressure gauge and sulfur dioxide gas flow meter, mounted on the front of each sulfonator cabinet, enable the operator to determine application characteristics and make adjustments. The optimum dosage is determined by measuring the residual chlorine at the process control sampling points and "automatically" adjusting the feed rate, initiated by an electrical signal from the residual analyzer.
The following are the main control points for the dechlorination system:

---Container Isolation Valves - shut-off valves for the chlorine container supplies.
---Header Valves - Secondary shut-off valves for the chlorine container supplies. 
---Sulfur Dioxide Ejector - creates a vacuum and allows the vacuum regulator to
       withdraw sulfur dioxide gas from one ton container.

---Vacuum Regulating Valve - reduces the pressurized gas to a vacuum demand supply.

A major safety concern is a sulfur dioxide leak in Dechlorination Building. The Bureau of Water and Wastewater has installed a wall mounted, Co

ntinuous Monitoring System Interscan sulfur dioxide gas detector. This device is mounted at eye level with a suction pipe located at floor level continuously sample air and detect any presence of sulfur dioxide gas. 

The facility uses an approximately 1,500 pounds per day (lb./day) of sulfur dioxide for dechlorination.
